correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

div.p:
NÍSHÁPÚR, or Néshápúr (Arabic, Naisábúr), the most important city of Khorâsân in the Middle Ages, but now much decayed. The second element of the name is that of the traditional founder Shahpuhr or Sapor. Some accounts name the first, others the second Sapor.
Spiegel, Eranisclιe AUcrthumskunde, iii. 254; Nöldeke, Gesch.der Perser. . .ausTabari, p. 59. The first syllable of the name appears to be Nêv, “good” (Noldeke, l.c.). The older name of the town or district was Abrashahr. The importance of the place under the Sasanians was in part religious; one of the three holiest fire-temples was in its neighbourhood.
Hoffmann, Syr.Aktenpers.Märtyrer, p. 290 sq. Nishâpùr under the Moslems contained a large Arab element; it became the capital of Khorâsân, and greatly increased in prosperity, under the almost independent princes of the house of Tahir (820-873 a.d.). Istakhri describes it as a well-fortified town, a league square, with a great export of cotton goods and raw silk. In the decline of the empire the city had much to suffer from the Turkomans, whose raids have in modern times destroyed the prosperity of this whole region. In 1153 it was utterly ruined by the Ghuzz Turkomans, but soon rose again, because, as Yâkùt remarks, its position gave it command of the entire caravan trade with the East. It was again taken and razed to the ground by the Mongols in 1221, but a century later Ibn Batιita found the city again flourishing, with four colleges, numerous students, and an export of silk-stuffs to India. Nishâpùr was famous for its fruits and gardens, which gave it the epithet of “little Damascus.”

The surname of Naisâbûri connects with the city a number of learned men, including Omar Khayyam(q.v.), the Hafiz Abιi 'Ali (oδ. 960), the Koran commentator Ahmed al-Tha'labi (o⅛. 1035), his disciple ΛVahidi, author of the famous Asbdbnozülal-Ko ’ rdn{ob. 1076), and the disciple of the latter, Maidani, the author of the well-known collection of Arabic proverbs. See further Kazwini, ii. 317 sq.
